guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

post.title: What do you believe is the best english translation of the Bible?

body:
I tend to read esv or gw translations, but I keep a hebrew and greek interlinear bible on hand, too. The esv has ease of reading, the gw is different enough to keep me from slipping into a daze, and the interlinears are good for answering specific translation inquiries. I will often swap to other translations on my app just to see what's different.

Imo there isn't one translation that's best, and you're most likely to understand the point if you use many translations. Insisting one translation is Holy and above all others is making a false god of the words rather than seeking the Word.

body: The Bible tells us God preserved his word, to say we cannot have a perfect translation is to call God a liar. KJV is the pure word of God, I do not worship my Bible but I do believe that God provided a word perfectly that we can know 100% what he said. To say there is not a perfect word that we can read is to also say that you dont know if something is reliable, if there is a 99% chance that the translation is ok, that means that there is always a chance that it is not correct, it is not trustworthy. The God of the universe made us, he can preserve his word above all else. These Bible "Scholars" that argue we cannot have a perfect word, argue to keep their grip on the people, they are the nicolaitans of the Revelation. Is it any wonder that the word nicolaitan comes from the greek roots that mean conquest and the people, or conquest of the people? They are modern day pharisees that wish to subvert the believers into their wickedness.

Quoting out of context scripture at each other till we're (proverbially) blue in the face is a big waste of time for both of us. 

If you want to goad others on this guild into your favorite argument, have at it, but you'll find no choice meat in me.

body:
None of them. For one, every single translation is extremely biased towards the doctrines of the translators, and this is pretty much unavoidable. Most of them are also full of confusing religious language instead of just normal words like those utilized in the original texts. I know of few versions that even leave as much as a note in passages that were probably added by scribes, or even entire books that were forgeries and teach heresy (not that we should worship the disciples in the first place. Have you ever read the gospels, they were complete idiots!). With the exception of the casting the first stone story of course, because they want to be able to support the death penalty. "It's only a later addition if I disagree with it!"

You should probably use an interlinear, and verify that the words are correct, and be aware of variant passages. And be especially mindful of when passages are suddenly interrupted with a sentence or so that supports something that sounds suspiciously like Roman, Catholic, Jewish, or Gnostic beliefs. Also keep in mind the context, don't follow the disciples over Jesus, and know which books are actually authentic.

body:
Show in me the Bible where it says to follow "The Bible", and since you said so, specifically the KJV. Hint: you won't, because "The Bible" didn't even exist until 382 when the Catholic Church decided to take centralized control of everything. The only quotes I've ever seen are about "scripture" which just means the word of God will be preserved and to hold firmly to it (and Jesus is the fulfillment of the old written scriptures anyway). Note that I said the word of *God*, not Paul, Peter, James, Moses, David, Solomon or whoever else. Before the Council of Rome they had the law (the pentacheuch and the gospels) and the prophets as sources. They were not letter perfect like you say but conveyed the same thing. The last portion was the regular writings, which was just famous religious works, often attributed to famous disciples. But it had that category for a reason. It contained a broad amount of works and what was included was not uniform. But it usually included the inter-testamental books as well as Enoch and a few others. They were not viewed as completely authoritative prior to Catholicism, but good for reading. However the "writings" from the apostles and old testament fathers were also included in this section (fun fact, the KJV also included the apocrypha in the 1611 edition). Idolatry of the disciples came later as a tool for the Roman Catholic Church to control people, as their writings were often twisted or even had passages added or books forged in their name to promote an agenda.

Be careful, there was a group in the New Testament who followed the letter above the spirit, and they were *not* praised for their lack of ears to hear and eyes to see.

Either way though, there are multiple english translations. What is it that makes the KJV the special perfect preserved 100.0% accurate one and no others?

body: Most of these people condemn the original languages too, saying they're not as inspired as the KJV for having tiny variants (yes, *literally*). They also think the "Alexandrian" text type is corrupt simply because it's from Egypt, even though the one used in the KJV is obviously the more smoothed-out version with quite a few more interpolations (though the Alexandrian is more poorly copied and omits some things by accident or out of convenience, but that's because of a longer transmission all the way to Egypt, not trying to change what it says).

body:
The final authority is supposed to be Jesus, not "The Bible" and certainly not specifically the KJV. Even in the old testament people were praised for not obeying disciples who conflicted with God, *even if they were prophets*. And now Jesus is the literal fulfillment of even those scriptures.

"The Bible" has several contradictions where the authors of the writings made a mistake, and those writings have also been edited to promote agendas, and some of them are even complete forgeries. The gospels give us a source for the word, the rest is merely additional.

body:
I come not to the conclusion that the KJV is the perfect word of God but that God made a perfect word for us in English. I know there is aperfect word out there because the Bible tells us so: 
Psalm 12:6 KJV 
>The words of the LORD are pure words: as silver tried in a furnace of earth, purified seven times.

2 Timothy 3:16 KJV
>All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness:

Then because if you examine the evidence and the facts beyond that too much for me to fully explain here, and certain men such as Dr. Bill Grady has done a better job than I could do in the examination of the evidence.

I agree with David here, because notice it says the words of *God*, not "The Bible". And this is a comment on the goodness of these words and that their promise will be kept and not broken. It's not about it being letter perfect.

> 2 Timothy 3:16

2 Timothy is a forgery that preaches several heretical doctrines at odds with the rest of the scriptures (aside from the other forgeries of course). In fact it seems to be almost a rebuttal of Paul's beliefs. It was probably forged by the Romans because its teachings sound suspiciously like the traditions of Greco-Roman pagan society. And even it isn't saying that any one text type is letter perfect or better than the others, it's saying to listen to them.

> Then because if you examine the evidence and the facts beyond that too much for me to fully explain here, and certain men such as Dr. Bill Grady has done a better job than I could do in the examination of the evidence.

The only evidence I can see is that the KJV is based on a more corrupt text and has translation errors because it was worked on by tiny teams of scholars with no internet. And it's also written in Jacobean English that you have to strain to understand. I'm all for doing that for greater accuracy but do it with the original language, not some translation made 1600 years later.

body:
> seeing as how Jesus is no longer on the earth in this human sense, we can't exactly ask him what he thinks

The gospels have plenty of accounts and they all line up with one another. We could get by relying solely on what he taught in them, and that is rather clear to those who have eyes to see and ears to hear.

Even a casual reading shows that the Majority Text (upon which the KJV is based) is the smoothed-out and "improved" version of the text. The Alexandrian witnesses do omit some things but that's out of mistake or convenience from copying such a long way, not trying to change it. Where that does not happen it is generally more faithful to the original reading. This makes perfect sense, as the Catholic and Orthodox churches developed they gained centralized control over the text, which means that the later versions would naturally have less variants than earlier copies. There is no evidence of Byzantine texts before the third century, aside from a few passages missing from the Alexandrian texts such as Mark 16:9-20 and even those are Alexandrian in character (and the Alexandrian texts we have all left a blank space for it).

On top of that the KJV has plenty of errors, mostly famously mistaking anything underground with hell. Another famous issue is that it includes 1 John 5:7, which was not found in *any* Greek text up to that time but Erasmus was forced to back translate it from the Vulgate by the Catholic Church.

> And I would cite some scripture for you but seeing as how you do not believe the apostle paul's books to be legitimate, there would be no point

I believe the ones actually written by Paul to be legitimate. I only reject the ones that were forged by the Catholic Church to insert Greco-Roman pagan doctrines into Christianity.

parent.body: Sir, seeing as how Jesus is no longer on the earth in this human sense, we can't exactly ask him what he thinks. God speaks to man through his inspired word. I condemn the idea that the Bible is not perfect. But hey perhaps you can point out these "contradictions" rather than just state they exist. There is a consensus of 90% of the manuscripts that are pure and those all agree with the KJV, I say that God made his word pure in those manuscripts and kept it pure in the KJV. Back it up with scripture and evidence please. And I would cite some scripture for you but seeing as how you do not believe the apostle paul's books to be legitimate, there would be no point, however I am not forced to meet upon your crazy notions but rather answer you on my own stance (one supported by the Bible wholly).

parent.body:
Show in me the Bible where it says to follow "The Bible", and since you said so, specifically the KJV. Hint: you won't, because "The Bible" didn't even exist until 382 when the Catholic Church decided to take centralized control of everything. The only quotes I've ever seen are about "scripture" which just means the word of God will be preserved and to hold firmly to it (and Jesus is the fulfillment of the old written scriptures anyway). Note that I said the word of *God*, not Paul, Peter, James, Moses, David, Solomon or whoever else. Before the Council of Rome they had the law (the pentacheuch and the gospels) and the prophets as sources. They were not letter perfect like you say but conveyed the same thing. The last portion was the regular writings, which was just famous religious works, often attributed to famous disciples. But it had that category for a reason. It contained a broad amount of works and what was included was not uniform. But it usually included the inter-testamental books as well as Enoch and a few others. They were not viewed as completely authoritative prior to Catholicism, but good for reading. However the "writings" from the apostles and old testament fathers were also included in this section (fun fact, the KJV also included the apocrypha in the 1611 edition). Idolatry of the disciples came later as a tool for the Roman Catholic Church to control people, as their writings were often twisted or even had passages added or books forged in their name to promote an agenda.

Be careful, there was a group in the New Testament who followed the letter above the spirit, and they were *not* praised for their lack of ears to hear and eyes to see.

Either way though, there are multiple english translations. What is it that makes the KJV the special perfect preserved 100.0% accurate one and no others?
